intro: Thelypodiopsis howellii, commonly known as Howell's sandmat, is a low-growing perennial plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the family Aizoaceae, commonly called the ice plant family, and is characterized by its fleshy, succulent leaves and small, star-shaped flowers. The plant thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often found in sandy or gravelly soils. Its adaptations include reduced leaf surface area to minimize water loss and the ability to store water in its thick, fleshy stems. Thelypodiopsis howellii plays a role in stabilizing sandy soils and providing habitat for small insects and animals.
